abstracts.cdata!:
The Investment Recovery Project for
            Croatia achieved its major objectives fully; the Bank and
            borrower performance were both satisfactory. The most
            important results included: a) new investments to
            enterprises, predominantly, Small and Medium Enterprises
            (SMEs); b) strengthening institutional capacity of
            Participating Commercial Banks (PCBs); c) increased
            competition in the financial sector; and d) establishment of
            sustained market for long and medium-term project finance.
            The project also had a positive impact on institutional
            building in Croatia. The implementation of the Institutional
            Development Plans (IDPs) was also successful, with most of
            the objectives achieved and activities completed though with
            some delays. During the Summer 2000, when the macro and
            financial situation was difficult and affected a number of
            banks, the Alpe Jadran Banka loan was suspended. AJB, in
            addition to systematic problems affecting the banking and
            enterprise sector, experienced corporate problems triggered
            by the split between to major owners followed by changes in
            the corporate structure of the bank. In Fall 2000, the
            project returned to a satisfactory rating, after
            cancellation of the AJB loan, and with the Dalmatinska Bank
            overcoming its difficulties.

abstracts.cdata!:
Specific development objectives of the
            Investment Recovery Project are to: (i) provide stimulus to
            private sector development through the financing of new
            investments in private or newly privatized enterprises in
            need of fresh capital for expansion or restructuring; (ii)
            support the Government's objective of promoting
            competition in the financial system by helping strengthen
            the institutional capacity of participating commercial banks
            (PCBs); and (iii) foster  development of a market of medium
            and long-term financing of investment projects.  The
            project's component will be a line of credit to PCBs to
            be on-lent to private sector enterprises.  These sub-loans
            may be used to finance capital investments and may include
            up to a 20 percent component of associated working capital.
